title: What makes a good rap lyric? - Quora

response.answer_text: What makes a good rap lyric? Errm, this is a somewhat difficult question. With differences in listeners’ expectations and general exposure to ‘good’ music, what seems good to a listener may appear horrible, average or even extra-terrestrial to another. There are some constants, however. Before I touch on them, I’d like to say that a good lyric may have nothing to do with excellent vocabulary or edge-cutting figures of speech. Most award-winning songs come with lyrics written in everyday English devoid of vocabulary or excessive use of simile, metaphors, hyperbole, etc. A good lyric may feature the following constants: a. A vivid storyline. From bar to bar, a rap lyric worthy of being called ‘good’ develops around a story line. The unfolding of events is orderly. It becomes easy to know what the music tries to preach in say, just a verse. b. Emotions. A good lyric should be capable of indulging your emotion and interest. You should RELATE to the artist’s feelings based on how he says what; virtually stepping in the musician’s shoes whether you’ve really had such experience or not. A good lyric makes you do that c. Intelligent construct/Punchline. Imagine being in Ireland but still thinking about London. Yes! Something got to hit u real hard yet sweet enough for u to daydream about for a few seconds while he workin his way around the words to hit u again after barely recovering from the first. (Only few can relate). d. Flawless Transitioning. Some artists tend to be more careless migrating a song from its verse into the chorus, a second verse ending well and effortlessly blending with the chorus, etc. A good lyric may not be one desperately looking for out-of-context words that sort of ‘rhyme’ well in order to blend with a chorus or bridge. e. A good lyric has this crazy I'm-here-to-kill aura. U can sense it when u read the first two, three, four lines. For this, i can’t explain. Its too sensory to be written. Thanks.

That all depends on what you are looking to get out of rap. The reason lyrics in any song are good to you is because 1) you enjoy the delivery 2) you understand the message and 3) you value the message that the lyrics are trying to convey. The same thing goes with rap, as good rap lyrics depend on what you like about the song  If you value the delivery of rap music and enjoy wordplay, and don't mind the message being a little shallow at times (a sort of mindless enjoyment. Not something you dig deep into and analyze for meaning but just something you can relax to and take in) then I would point you towards fast rappers (aka "choppers") Their rap style and lyrics are all based around performance and sounding like badasses. (Tech N9ne, Twista, Busta Rhymes, etc). Other rappers are just like fast rappers, but slower. These "regular" rappers are what you generally find in the mainstream (Lil Wayne, 2 Chainz, Tyga, etc. personally my least favorite category) Then there is rap with a message.  These rappers have a delivery style of regular or fast rappers, only their lyrics have undertones, metaphors, thought out and dissectable messages. If you are looking for this type of rap, I would recommend listening to certain songs by MURS (Everything, Love And Appreciation, and No More Control are good examples). My favorite rapper with a message is hands down Watsky. I could give you probably about twenty song recommendations, but I'll narrow it down to about 5: Never Let It Die, Sloppy Seconds, Cardboard Castles, All You Can Do and Tiny Glow Screens (both parts).  So yeah, long answer. Sorry about that. If you have any questions I'd love to answer them!

A good rap verse/song must contain: Some level of literary devices (metaphors, similes, wordplay, multisyllabic and/or internal rhymes)An above-average vocabularyA good flowSome sort of message and/or emotionA sonically pleasing soundA good instrumentalAgain, 1 or 2 of these could be non-existent in a song, yet being good, but that’s a rare case.
